title: brit rich kids bali party instagram
story: VIDEO of dozens of rich kids partying in a luxury villa in Bali amid the coronavirus pandemic has sparked fury online.Outraged Indonesians slammed revellers including a British Instagram star and two Russian models who flouted social distancing rules at the birthday bash on Sunday.Video footage shared online showed a DJ playing as more than  glamorous Westerners boozed and mingled in the sprawling villa in North Kuta.A Brit behind the camera jokes: Nothing low key about this!Indonesia does not have a formal coronavirus lockdown but residents have been instructed to stay indoors and avoid gatherings.It was reported that police have interviewed the playboy party host after the footage caused fury in the conservative country.Social media users called the party shameful and called on those involved to be kicked out of Bali.One said: If you cant follow the rules, go back to your own country.Another clip showed guests laughing outside with the caption: Gassed up proper now.It was posted online by Manchester-born tattoo model and influencer Tyrone Hermitt, who had , followers on Instagram but closed his account after a backlash online.Tyrone - who romanced Ferne McCann on Es Celebs Go Dating - posted an apology to the Bali locals online yesterday.He said: This was not my party. I apologise for attending. I did not realise there was going to be as much people at the party and it looked more busy than it was.I respect Bali and will be donating to some charities to help locals who are losing jobs and need help.Tyrone was also seen riding a motorbike with a pal after leaving the party.Also seen in the video are Russian social media star Ksenia Aldoshenko and model Dorokhova Ksenia.The party was hosted by playboy pilot Mahmoud Attiya, originally from Egypt, to celebrate his st birthday.He also apologised, telling local media alongside an official: We are very sorry for all the trouble.We only invited few people but a lot of people showed up so we had a call from security and we closed the DJ and everybody left.We totally appreciate the Bali government and immigration and their support to help avoid Covid-.Indonesia has struggled to impose effective lockdown measures as officials believe the millions of uneducated citizens will not follow rules on social distancing.One village has hired actors dressed as ghosts to scare residents back indoors at night.The country has also closed its borders, meaning tourists and expats already there cannot leave.Tyrone said on social media he was in Bali hoping to start a business.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: open windows coronavirus home
story: KEEPING your windows and curtains open could reduce the spread of coronavirus in your house.Not only could the air flow prevent the virus from settling on surfaces, experts have suggested.How long the virus can survive on surfaces is still debated, but studies have found surviving particles on plastic and stainless steel for as long as three days after contact.Meanwhile, past studies looking at other viruses suggest natural light could make it harder for the new strain of coronavirus to thrive in homes.Scientists from the University of Calornia explained that open windows with natural light could break it down.A previous study looking at the flu virus found its half le - how long it takes for the virus to no longer be active - was . minutes in a dark room, compared to . minutes in sunlight, according to Yahoo.While scientists admit that more research is needed in regard to the impact natural light has on the virus indoors, researchers added that daylight exists as a free, widely available resource to building occupants with little downside to its use and many documented positive human health benefits.Some have suggested that UV light can destroy the virus - although this has been debunked.Expert Dan Arnol, who works for UV Light Technology providing disinfecting equipment to hospitals and other locations, explained that the only UV light which would destroy it, isnt safe for humans to come into contact with.UVA and UVB, the two main two main UV rays emitted by the sun, cannot destroy the virus, while UVC, the UV ray which is filtered out by the atmosphere and doesnt reach the surface, can.But Dan told the BBC: UVC is really nasty stuff – you shouldnt be exposed to it. It can take hours to get sunburn from UVB, but with UVC it takes seconds.A study on the Sars virus also found little effect, with the virus remaining unchanged after being exposed to UVA for  minutes.WHO have urged people not to use UV lamps to sterilise hands or other areas of skin in a bid to beat coronavirus.The organisation said: UV lamps should not be used to sterilise hands or other areas of skin as UV radiation can cause skin irritation.While natural light from outside may help sht the virus, air flow could change how the virus settles in your house.Other research published in the American Society for Microbiology’s journal mSystems added that the air could increase outside air fraction and increase total air change rate which would stop the virus settling on a surface.Previous studies looking at other infectious diseases, including Sars and influenza also found a reduction in the spread of the virus in buildings with better ventilation and air movement.However, scientists add it could later settle on another surface, so additional measures of hand washing are still recommended.Coronavirus can live in the air for hours, according to new research.Researchers used a nebulizer device to put samples of the virus into the air, the same way it would end up theresomeone were to cough.They found the virus, still viable, could be detected in the air up to three hours later. A shocking new animation has proven that the UKs two metre - or six feet - social distancing rule might not be enough to keep you safe during the pandemicyoure out jogging.Tech company Ansys created a video which reveals you could come into contact with droplets of Covid- evenyou stay six feet behind another person while you are walking, running or cycling.The experts say that because of this running side-by-side could be less risky than in single file, as you are far less likely to be struck with any potentially infected fluids.The Sun has launched an appeal to raise £MILLION for NHS workers.The Who Cares Wins Appeal aims to get vital support to staff in their hour of need.We have teamed up with NHS Charities Together in their urgent Covid- Appeal to ensure the money gets to exactly who needs it.The Sun is donating £, and we would like YOU to help us raise a million pounds, to help THEM.No matter how little you can spare, please donate today herewww.thesun whocareswinsappealOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: mobile phone vandalised coronavirus conspiracy 5g easter
story: DOZENS of mobile phone masts were vandalised over the Easter weekend as bizarre coronavirus conspiracy G theories continue to spread online.Around  phone masts were damaged across the UK over the four-day weekend - doubling the amount of attacks seen.Bogus claims that G causes coronavirus have been dismissed as nonsense by scientists, but vital masts continue to be targeted by thugs.Mobile UK, which represents the four big mobile networks who own and operate all the UK’s phone masts, said the senseless damage is affecting our vital first-responders.Spokesman Gareth Elliott said: “These story: Heres when you can expect yours to hit.The Internal Revenue Service announced via Twitter money had already hit the accounts of some recipients.They said they sent out the first round of funds on April .#IRS deposited the first Economic Impact Payments into taxpayers bank accounts today, the agency wrote.We know many people are anxious to get their payments well continue issuing them as fast as we can.The deposits will continue in the coming days, starting with people who already filed their  or  tax s and have authorized direct deposit.Others - including those who havent filed tax s, authorized direct deposits, or receive Social Security - will likely have to wait weeks or even months before receiving their money.The money will appear automatically in your bank accountthe IRS has your information from previous tax s.Butthe IRS doesn’t have the info, oryou didn’t file taxes in the previous two years, you can submit your information on their website.The checks are part of the . trillion economic relief package passed by Congress last month.Under the CARES Act, iniduals will receive up to ,, while couples will get up to ,, plus an extra  per child.Payouts decline above the , to , mark, ending at , for indviduals and , for married couples.It depends on your income, according to The New York Times.The newspaper reported that single adults who have an adjusted gross income of , or less will get the full amount.Taxpayers who are head of their household will get the full paymentthey earned , or less, the Times reported.However, residents with certain income levels will not be eligible.For example, a family with two children will not be eligible for paymentsits income surpassed ,, according to The Times.Do you have a story for The US Sun team Email us at exclusive@the-sun or call   .Like us on Facebook at www.facebook TheSunUS and follow us from our main Twitter account at @TheSunUS.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: charles ingram where is he now
story: The ex-Army Major swindled the show with the help of we Diana and a coughing accomplice, Tecwen Whittock.Born in Shardlow, Derbyshire, in , Ingram obtained a degree in civil engineering and a masters in corporate management before joining the Army in .He became an officer with the Royal Engineers and rose to the rank of major in .Ingram served in Bosnia for six months on Nato peacekeeping duties.He was forced to resign from the Army in August  following his court case.Diana Ingram is the we of former Major Charles, with the pair getting married in .The couple met while she was training to be a teacher at Barry College in South Wales, going onto have three children.She had already appeared on Who Wants To Be A Millionaire  prior to her husbands appearances, winning £, - the same as her brother Adrian Pollock also won.In , Major Charles Ingram answered  questions correctly to sensationally scoop the jackpot on Who Wants To Be A Millionaire A court ruled he had answered the questions through help from fellow contestant Tecwen Whittock, who coughed to alert him to the right answers.Ingrams we was also said to be involved.Whittock, a college lecturer from Cardf, was waiting in the fastest finger first group when the controversy erupted.A few days after the show, Ingram received a message to call Paul Smith, the boss of the company which made the show.Mr Smith said there were irregularities during the taping of the show and it would not be aired.Police had also been contacted.It was suggested Whittock had been coughing loudly to indicate the right answer, and blew his nose loudly when the major was about to give a wrong answer.Pagers and mobile phones had been used to help, it was claimed.The  Southwark Crown Court trial lasted four weeks and heard evidence from Ingram claiming the video tape of the show was unfairly manipulated.He insisted he didnt notice the coughing but  coughs were recorded during the second night of the show -  from the ten Fastest Finger First contestants, with  of these signicant.Prosecutors said these coughs were from Whittock, who claimed to have suffered a persistent cough for his entire le.All three were convicted of procuring the execution of a valuable security by deception on April , .Both Diana and Charles were given an  month prison sentence suspended for two years, while Whittock received a  month sentence suspended for two years.After he was sentenced, the Army Board forced Ingram to resign as major after  years of service.Despite this, he went on to remain a TV personality and made several appearances on competition reality shows.He took part in The Weakest Link with his we Diane, while he also competed in The Game alongside former Liberty X singer Kevin Simm.Charles starred in Channel s We Swap, where he swapped his we for Jade Goody.It emerged in  that Ingram paid only £, of the £, fine he was given in  — despite his court case costing the taxpayer more than £million.He retreated to his home in Westbury, Wilts, selling jewellery made by Diana on a market stall.In October , The Sun revealed he was flogging homemade brooches for £ and necklaces for up to £.The Sun tracked down the cheat and found him loading up his belongings into a van to move to a flat on a remote farm.He decided to sell his £, country home after the scandal turned him into a recluse.Charles was last spotted selling jewellery in a Christmas market stall in Bath in , he had declared himself as bankrupt for the fourth time just months before.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: debenhams uk store closures latest
story: Read on to find out which branches are set to close, and why.Debenhams revealed in April  that it was continuing with plans set before it went into administration to close  stores in .As a result of falling into administration again in April , it also decided to axe all  of its shops in Ireland.It had previously closed  stores in January , including Altrincham, Wolverhampton, Ashford and Wimbledon.Weve asked Debenhams how many stores its closed in total over the past few years and well update this story as soon as we get a response.Debenhams told us the exact locations of the  stores set to close next year are still to be determined.It currently has  shops remaining.Debenhams went into administration in April .Its the second time the department store chain has gone bust in a year and also follows a company voluntary arrangement- a type of insolvency process.Debenhams has appointed business advisory firm FRP Advisory to oversee the process.The -year-old retailer last entered administration in April .Back then, a group of banks and hedge funds led by US firm Silver Point Capital took control of the struggling retailer which wiped out the investments of shareholders, including Sports Direct billionaire Mike Ashley.But stores remained open and the retailer says this time round it will work to re-open as many stores as possible when coronavirus related lockdown restrictions are lted.Debenhams website is currently trading as normal and it even has a half price Easter sale on.Stefaan Vansteenkiste, chief executive officer of Debenhams, said: The appointment of the administrators will protect our business, our employees, and other important stakeholders, so that we are in a position to resume trading from our stores.We are desperately sorry not to be able to keep the Irish business operating but are faced with no alternative option in the current environment.Customers are still able to spend their gt cards online and in storesas normal.But shoppers might want to consider using any gt cards they have while the retailer is still accepting them.Debenhams points out that online, you can only use one gt card per transaction.Returns are still being accepted as usual.But again, you might want to consider ing or exchanging items sooner rather than later to be on the safe side - thatsyoure able to do so safely during lockdown.You should also consider putting new purchases on credit card as this will give you greater protectionsomething goes wrong with the purchase and youre unable to get your money back from Debenhams.Debit card purchases also offer some protection, but not to the same extent as those offered by credit cards.

title: nearly 20 covidiots play cricket lockdown
story: NEARLY  men were caught playing cricket in a park because they were “bored” during the coronavirus lockdown.The selfish group were stopped by police on Moor Park in Preston after heading out with a bat and ball yesterday afternoon.The cricketers were caught on camera by Paul Winstanley, who shared a short clip of them on Twitter in the park, tagging Lancashire Police.Paul wrote:  people enjoying a game of cricket... how stupid can you be.... idiotsLancashire Police’s tactical ops team replied: “Ourselves and colleagues from Lancs Specials attended a report of several males playing cricket on Moor Park, Preston.“ adult males who claimed to be ‘bored’ have been suitably advised regarding social distancing.”People were less than impressed with the cricketers’ antics and said they should have been slapped with penalties.One man fumed: “Advice not acceptable, fines would be more appropriate, are these people above the rest of us that they do not need comply.”Another said: “Should have been fined. If people see this lenient behaviour others will do the same.“Surely out of  adults one of them has a brain cell  Or not.”One woman tweeted: “Its past the ‘advised’ stage now dont you think “Fine them or nick them. People arent going to stop nor show respect unless you are allowed to do this.”Despite a few covidiots in Preston - beaches, parks and green spaces across the country looked deserted as Brits finally took notice of the government’s plea to stay home over Easter.Park benches and outdoor gyms were taped off by councils in a bid to deter crowds from loitering as parts of the UK saw highs of C on Saturday and Sunday.But the colder start to Sunday seemed to put most from venturing outside, with a Met Office meteorologist saying it was a shock to the system for some places.However, in north London one group of women were swtly told to go home after being caught picnicking in Primrose Hill.The friends sat on the grass with snacks and bikes but were soon stopped by Camden Council workers.The Sun has launched an appeal to raise £MILLION for NHS workers.The Who Cares Wins Appeal aims to get vital support to staff in their hour of need.We have teamed up with NHS Charities Together in their urgent Covid- Appeal to ensure the money gets to exactly who needs it.The Sun is donating £, and we would like YOU to help us raise a million pounds, to help THEM.No matter how little you can spare, please donate today herewww.thesun whocareswinsappeal It comes as foreign secretary Dominic Raab warned that lockdown measures could continue for at least another three weeks.Mr Raab said Covid-’s peak in the UK was probably still a week away and he predicted the lockdown to continue until at least May .He told No’s daily press conference yesterday: “This week SAGEwill review the measures.We will consider their assessment based on the evidence at that point.We dont expect to make any changes.And we wont until we are as confident as we can be that any such changes can be made.He said it was far too early to talk about lting the lockdown and that any suggestion of relaxing the restrictions would be getting ahead of ourselves.

title: coronavirus prime ministers questions go
story: NewsCoronavirus: Prime Ministers Questions will go ahead in new virtual ParliamentMPs could be back in a virtual House of Commons this month as plans get underway to allow debates to take place despite the Covid- lockdownShareCommentsByNicola BartlettPolitical Correspondent:,  APR Updated:,  APR News " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWe will use your email address to send you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailPrime Ministeraposs Questions couldthis month as plans get underway for a virtual Parliament. MPs and Peers will be able to hold Commons and Lords debates through video conferencing - and work is underway to develop a way for online voting. A skeleton crew of MPs - including Speaker Lindsay Hoyle - would attend the Commons in person, wherever possible. But for the most part, debates would be conducted online.Oral questions PMQs , urgent questions and ministerial statements are planned to take place during the first two hours of each sitting day, by video link.Planning for certain parts of House business to be taken virtually when it s on  April “is progressing well”, Speaker Sir Lindsay Hoyle has said.   The proceedings will be broadcast  webcast as live – and once the delivery of them is judged satisfactory and sustainable, the House will consider extending the model to debates on motions and legislation, the Speaker said.   It will also be up to the House to decide on any change to “a system of remote voting in isions of the House,” he added.  Sir Lindsay outlined the behind-the-scenes preparations that have been taking place tothe House of Commons to work on  April in a letter to MPs.   He conceded that while “the scale of the challenge means there are bound to be bumps along the way”, the use of technology will allow Members to hold the Government to account, but in line with important public health guidance.   Explaining the measures, he said: “Planning for certain parts of House business to be taken virtually is progressing well.   “The main aspect of the proposal will allow oral questions – including PMQs – urgent questions and statements to take place at the beginning of each sitting day by video link.”   A virtual meeting of the Procedure Committee will consider this model on Wednesday,  April.   If the House of Commons Commission gives its approval on Thursday,  April, it would be for  the Leader of the House, following consultation with the parties, to put forward motions setting out any temporary arrangements for the House to consider on  April.  The House of Commons shouldin an almost entirely virtual form, with extensive opportunities for MPs to question ministers about the coronavirus response, constitutional experts have said. They suggested that lower priority parliamentary business should be sidelined to increase the ability of MPs to hold Boris Johnson and his Government to account.Professor Meg Russell, from University College London, and Dr Ruth Fox, from the Hansard Society think- tank, said any changes must be temporary and should not be used to sht power away from Parliament to the Government. Commons business will resume on April  after an extended Easter break, despite calls for an early recall. Prof Russell, director of the constitution unit at UCL, and Dr Fox suggested that as far as possible MPs should stay away from Westminster in the interests of safety and to set a national example. Commons Speaker Sir Lindsay Hoyle has already suggested that MPs should be allowed to participate in proceedings virtuallythe physical presence of members, or too many members, in the palace is not appropriate. The suggestions from Prof Russell and Dr Fox include:The introduction of electronic voting The ability to have three or four urgent questions, lasting up to  minutes each, every sitting day Giving MPs the chance to ask follow-up questions at Prime Ministeraposs Questions An increased frequency in appearances by the Prime Minister, or whoever is deputising for him as he recovers from coronavirus, before the Liaison Committee The possible introduction of a Coronavirus Select Committee.The pair acknowledged that a sht to a virtual Parliament may present dficulties for media coverage. But they argued thatlive broadcast is temporarily compromised, that may be a necessary price to pay - and committees have already experimented with delayed broadcasts and video clips. Prof Russell said: There is clearly a widespread desire to get Parliament up and running again, and members will be keen to co-operate and will hopefully be flexible, accepting that virtual working will require some compromises. But itaposs really, really important that the Government does not just present members with a fait accompli - there needs to be proper consultation, and any changes should be strictly time-limited, with opportunities for feedback and regular review. Dr Fox said: Adversarial party politics rightly takes a back seat in a time of national crisis, but Parliamentaposs collective responsibility to hold the executive to account is enduring. Extraordinary arrangements are neededParliament is to go fully aposvirtualapos. But any new arrangements must ensure fair representation for all members and parties and the crisis and Parliamentaposs response to it should not become a pretext to sht power even further towards the executive. The Government is expected to set out its approach for Parliamentaposslater this week.

title: coronavirus tests been given only
story: NewsCoronavirus tests have been given to only  social care workers in BritainWhile , key healthcare workers and their families have had tests, just  have been carried out so far on stricken care home or other social care staffShareCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  APR Updated:,  APR NewsThe government is accused of treating care home residents like second-class citizens " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWe will use your email address to send you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailOnly  social care workers in Britain have had coronavirus tests, the government admitted today. Downing Street said specic testing of care home and home-care staff had only rolled out in the last few days due to a lack of capacity. As of am on Easter Monday, just  have been tested - compared to , once NHS staff and their families are included.  The tiny figure was revealed despite the Health Secretary pledging on Friday that all key social care staff could now get testsneeded.And it comes amid an outcry over hundreds of deaths from coronavirus in care homes - with  separate homes hit as of yesterday. Carers say they have been abandoned to their fate without enough protective equipment. Care home workers are struggling to get tested despite Michael Goveaposs daughter being given a test - allowing him toto work. Downing Street defended the test for Mr Goveaposs daughter, which was on the advice of Chief Medical Officer Chris Whitty. A No spokesman said yesterday: The minister in charge of the Cabinet Office is a central role in the coronavirus response. Testing a member of the household ensured that Michael Gove could get back to work to drive forward the governmentaposs response at a critical time. Shadow Care Minister Liz Kendall said: “It is extremely worrying that only  social care workers have so far been tested.“Around . million people work in social care, supporting vulnerable elderly and disabled people in their own homes and in residential care. “The Government must act urgently to ensure front line care staff get the testing and PPE they need to keep people safe and avoid even more deaths from this awful virus.” It may be that more than  social care workers were tested in total,they were classed as NHS staff or hospital inpatients but not recorded separately. Official figures today showed there have been  Covid- deaths outside hospital, including  in care homes, registered up to April . And because of the time lag the real number of care home deaths will be far higher. Work and Pensions Secretary Therese Coffey today claimed there were about , care home deaths. Former pensions minister Baroness Altmann warned elderly people feel they are being treated like lambs to the slaughter.  Despite a pledge to reach , tests a day by April  and , by April , no single day has seen more than , tests in Britain so far. On Friday Matt Hancock, the Health Secretary, announced there was finally enough capacity to test all NHS staff and families who needed it. But aides confirmed he was still trying to expand capacity far enough to offer it to all care home staff. And on Easter Sunday there were just , tests in the  hours from am, a signicant drop. The Prime Ministeraposs official spokesman said the lower overall figure “reflects the fact we’ve just been through bank holiday weekend”.

title: government says ibuprofen safe take
story: NewsGovernment says ibuprofen safe to take after concerns over coronavirusEarly studies had suggested that it could aggravate the condition and last month the NHS advised patients against taking the painkiller because of the risksShareByNicola BartlettPolitical Correspondent:,  APR News" to FREE email alerts from Mirror - politicsSubscribeWe will use your email address to send you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid Email The government has told patients that there is not enough evidence to suggest that that taking ibuprofen could make someone more likely to get coronavirus or make the symptoms worse for patients.Early studies had suggested that it could aggravate the condition and last month the NHS advised patients against taking the painkiller because of the risks. But now the Commission on Human Medicines has published its findings concluding there is currently insufficient evidence to establish a linkIt follows research from King’s College London  who analysed  studies on other coronavirus strains including SARS, to find outpain medications should be avoided.Their analysis found ‘no evidence’ that ibuprofen makes symptoms worse in patients with the disease. In a statement about the study, the researchers, led by Dr Mieke Van Hemelrijck, said: “There had been some speculation that non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugssuch as ibuprofen might make things worse for some Covid- patients, but the researchers did not find evidence to support this statement.” The Commission of Human Medicines Expert Working Group said: Patients can take paracetamol or ibuprofen when self-medicating for symptoms of COVID-, such as fever and headache, and should follow NHS advicethey have any questions orsymptoms get worse.  Last month chief scientic adviser Sir Patrick Vallance suggested people should not take ibuprofen as there were concerns.

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailEvery Thursday at pm, the nation has stood still to clap for carers - the millions of NHS staff and social care workers saving lives from coronavirus. Among those applauding have been Boris Johnson, Dominic Raab and other senior Tory ministers. Because of this, thousands have shared a  story - including on the Mirror - that showed Tory MPs cheering as they blocked a full pay rise for nurses. The story isnapost fake news: Tory MPs did vote down a proper pay rise for nurses in  and they did cheer when the vote was announced. However, itaposs inevitable that some details are lost in translation or over the passage of time. So as a public service, hereaposs what you need to know about the vote. What happened on  June   Tory and DUP MPs defeated a Labour amendment to the  Queenaposs Speech in the House of Commons. Among other things, the amendment aimed to call on the Government to end the public sector pay cap and give the emergency and public services a fair pay rise. However, it was voted down by  votes to .  Tory MPs and  DUP MPs voted against the amendment. In favour were  Labour MPs,  SNP MPs,  Lib Dem MPs,  Plaid Cymru,  Green and  Independent. What was actually blocked     The amendment would not have given nurses and other NHS staff a legally binding pay rise. But it would have sent a powerful and, arguably, a morally binding signal that what they were getting wasnapost enough. At the time of the vote, annual pay rises for NHS staff were still capped at the % a year that theyaposd been since . The amendment also called for a number of other things - see below. So did the government refuse completely to give nurses a pay rise   No. Itaposs completely true that at the time of the vote, the government hadnapost confirmed any extra help for NHS staff other than a % rise every year. Thataposs why MPsapos decision angered many campaigners and NHS workers at the time. But the following year, in summer , the government did eventually confirm NHS staff would get a three-year deal worth between .% and %. Critics of the government would argue that it only changed its course because of years of pressure by Labour, including that vote on  June . Meanwhile, No officials had also made noises about changing policy on the day of the vote, only for their message to be mired in confusion. At pm, a Downing Street spokesman said then-PM Theresa May had heard the message of the election and would listen to pay reviews which have branded the cap unsustainable. But pressed for more detail at pm, the Prime Ministeraposs official spokesman in No then told journalists repeatedly: Our policy has not changed.    It depends who you ask. Labour would say itaposs because they didnapost have NHS staff high enough up their priority list - and werenapost prepared to help them after years of Tory austerity. Tories, on the other hand, accused Labour of using the issue as a political football by lumping in lots of other complaints into the amendment. The amendment couldnapost be split into dferent bits, so had to be either approved or rejected all in one go. Then-Health Secretary Jeremy Hunt said just before the vote: The party of the NHS is not the party that uses it to milk votes it is the party that fights to make it better for patients. And so it was that Tory whips ordered their MPs to vote against the amendment - and it was defeated. Itaposs worth saying the resounding result came despite some Tory MPs wanting to see nurses get a pay rise. One of them, former nurse Maria Caulfield, said nursesapos pay cannot be right and urged a complete rethink. Why did MPs cheer     The simple answer is - because they won. As explained above, the vote came at the end of a torturous day in Westminster where the debate descended into angry party politics. The government, which had a tiny working majority, was relieved to have won by a comfortable margin. So Tory MPs who cheered were gripped by that party-political excitement rather than deliberately putting across a message to NHS workers. But in doing so they created a scene that, in retrospect, appeared insulting and disrespectful to many NHS workers. What was the full text of the amendment  But respectfully regret that the [Queenaposs] Speech fails to end cuts to the police and the fire service commend the response of the emergency services to the recent terrorist attacks and to the Grenfell Tower fire call on the Government to recruit more police officers and fire-fighters and further call on the Government to end the public sector pay cap and give the emergency and public services a fair pay rise.

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA greater understanding of coronavirus and its symptoms has emerged as more people are struck down by the disease. The most common symptoms of the virus are a dry cough and high temperature - with the government saying anyone who experiences these must self-isolate for seven days. However, less common signs being reported by those infected include lesions on the feet, testicular pain and a strange aposbuzzingapos or aposfizzingapos sensation on the skin. Others have reported feeling increased levels of mental fatigue or aposbrain fogapos shortly before being diagnosed. Hereaposs a list of some of the less common symptoms that are being increasingly reported by sufferers:Follow all coronavirus updates here on our live blogNeeding the toilet  Another mild symptom of coronavirus that is being reported with increased regularity is the need to go to the toilet more often. Dr Diana Gall explained to the  Express : Digestion problems and changes in bowel habits - particularly looser stools and making more frequent trips to the toilet - are sometimes the first signs that you’re coming down with something, not just with this coronavirus.However, diarrhoea has been reported as an early symptom in patients who have later tested positive for Covid-. A new study, published in the American Journal of Gastroenterology, analysed data  patients with Covid- in China’s Hubei province and found nearly  per cent had diarrhoea, vomiting or abdominal pain. Testicular pain  Another slightly less common symptom of the coronavirus, is testicular pain. Researchers from Hard Medical School  filed a case report about a -year-old man who tested positive for the virus, after going to hospital with a ‘stabbing pain’ in his testicles. While doctors could find nothing wrong with his testicles, and CT scan showed damage in his lungs. Two days later, the man was diagnosed with Covid-. A buzzing sensation One of the more curious symptoms is a buzzing sensation that runs through the body. While it has not been listed as an official symptom to watch out for, many people have posted online about experiencing a aposfizzingapos feeling. Tarana Burke, recognised as the founder of the #MeToo movement, said that her partner had the illness and the sensation that his aposskin felt like it was burningapos. Twitter user @Miafia described having “an electric feeling on my skin.”Dr Daniel Grfin, chief of infectious disease at ProHealth Care Associates in the US, has suggested the feeling may be part of an auto-immune response to a patientsapos nervous system.“Clearly it’s been identied, but we’re just not sure yet how widespread it is,” he told the New York Post. Foot lesions  Medical experts in Spain are currently investigating whether those who have the virus could be identied by small lesions on the feet.Last Thursday, The Spanish General Council of Official Podiatrist Colleges shared a statement revealing that several  coronavirus  patients had lesions on their feet.The statement said: They are purple lesionswhich usually appear on the toes and normally heal without leaving a mark. They added that it was a curious finding which had also been observed in numerous  Covid- patients in Italy and France, as well as Spain, according to dermatologists and podiatrists. The lesions were more commonly noticed in younger people with the virus, including teenagers and children, although some adults were also found to have them. Tummy ache  As with a loss of appetite, enduring a tummy ache may easily be passed off as a sign of something more innocuous. However, a newly published study by the American Journal of Gastroenterology links tummy problems to Covid-. They found that .% of  people who have been infected by the coronavirus in Chinaaposs Hubei province had digestive symptoms such as diarrhoea that can cause tummy pain, A dry cough  Perhaps the most recognisable of the Covid- symptoms, given how dferent it can sound compared to a typical cough. The cough is generally new for you - or dferentyou generally have a smokeraposs cough - and persistant. More often than not it will last for at least half a day or longer. Loss of taste and smell Some of the infected have reported experiencing a lack of smell and taste – known as anosmia - despite not having the usual signs of a cough or fever. It is now believed to be a symptom for hidden carriers of Covid-. Professor Nirmal Kumar, head of ENT UK, has urged Britons to self-isolatethey have this symptom. He told Sky News: In young patients, they do not have any signicant symptoms such as the cough and fever, but they may have just the loss of sense of smell and taste, which suggests that these viruses are lodging in the nose. In a statement, ENT UK said: “There is already good evidence from South Korea, China and Italy that signicant numbers of patients with proven covid- infection have developed anosmia hyposmia . Mental fatigue or aposbrain fogapos  Although this has not been officially chalked up as a symptom, Covid- sufferers have reported experiencing mental fatigue.Thea Jourdan told the Mail  that she first thought she may have been infected when she got a tickle in her throat and a headache.The mum-of-three then began to experience brain fog. Initially I felt exhausted, asI was dragging myself through treacle and had no choice but to go to my bed. I had no meaningful cough and I wasn’t running a fever, the Hampshire woman told the publication. But I had a peculiar sensation of something settling deep within my lungs, almost like breathing in talcum powder. Others have also reported struggling to hold on to thoughts or remember things throughout the day.

story: NewsAmount of tech owned by Brits in a letime and its trade-in value on musicMagpieResearch commissioned by musicMagpie found almost a fth of adults will simply bin their tech once theyve finished with it - eventhe device is still in working orderShareCommentsByAstrid HallJoseph WilkesReporter:,  APR NewsThe average Brit owns  games controllers in their letime " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - daily newsSubscribeWe will use your email address to send you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThe typical adult will spend around £, on tech during their letime, according to a study. This will include  mobile phones,  games consoles and  laptops or computers - along with more than , batteries and  charging cables. They will also purchase a total of  TVs,  tablets and  cameras - not forgetting  pairs of headphones and  sets of speakers. However, the research commissioned by musicMagpie, found almost a fth of adults will simply bin their tech once theyaposve finished with it - eventhe device is still in working order. And more than a third of the , adults polled will hang on to their old gadgets because they aposdonapost know what  to do with them.apos It also emerged the average adult could currently make £,. from trading in the tech in their home, based on the average value musicMagpie will pay customers when they sell technology items. Liam Howley, from musicMagpie, said: Our research has shown that people will own a staggering amount of tech during their letime, much of which will currently be dormant in households, as people donapost know what to do with it after itaposs no longer in use. With spring well underway and people currently being encouraged to stay at home, perhaps this is a good opportunity to have a rummage in those drawers to see what devices can be cleared out. But itaposs wasteful to just leave them tucked away in drawers, and not environmentally friendly to dump them in a bin. By trading in used tech, people can not only make extra cash for themselves, but will ensure their tech is refurbished for the next person to use. The study also found those polled will own  PC monitors,  smartwatches and  MP players during their letime. And during a typical year they will spend almost £ on the latest gadgets and gizmos, with another £.-a-month spent on contracts for devices such as mobile phones. But while three in five claim they aposcouldnapost liveapos without their beloved tech, more than a fth said they tend to replace their old devices because they have become dated. More than two thirds usually purchase new gadgets because their old one has stopped working. It also emerged that when it comes to dumping the products they no longer use,  per cent arenapost sure about how to recycle tech and dispose of it responsibly.  But nearly three quarters have never heard of the term apose-wasteapos - a term to describe discarded electrical items - despite  per cent admitting they contribute to this. And while  per cent recycle whatever they can of plastics, just  per cent have recycled electronics. A quarters have actually made money from recycling old gadgets by selling them on to be recycled or refurbished. But hanging onto the old gadgets could result in lost money as data shows the value of a new iPhone can depreciate by up to £-a-year and Samsung models by up to £. The study also found that despite  per cent of those polled recognising the importance of recycling electronics to help care for the environment,  per cent are more likely to replace a damaged gadget.

story: NewsBrit, , who thought he was cured tests positive for coronavirus after flightThe British man had been hospitalised in Danang City in Vietnam but after being declared healthy and free of coronavirus he headed for a flight home from Tan Son Nhat AirportShareCommentsByMichael Leidig:,  APR Updated:,  APR NewsPeople wearing personal protective equipments wait as they check in at Noi Bai international airport in Hanoi " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWe will use your email address to send you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA British man who was declared clear of coronavirus later tested positive for the bug after an internal flight in Vietnam. It meant dozens of people - including plane passengers - have had to be quarantined. The British man had been hospitalised in Danang City in Vietnam, but after being declared free of the virus, he had headed for the flight back home from the countryaposs Tan Son Nhat Airport. Local health Department boss Nguyen Tan Binh confirmed late yesterday that the British tourist tested positive shortly before catching the flight at the airport after being discharged from Danang Hospital following treatment for a coronavirus infection. They said that the -year-old man, who was not named, had been admitted to hospital on March  and released on the March  after testing negative three times. After that, he had been quarantined for another two weeks at a hotel in Danang City in line with guidelines issued by the Health Ministry. He had then flown to Ho Chi Minh City at the end of last week and was tested while staying at an airport hotel while waiting for the next flight. He had actually boarded the flight when the cityaposs Centre for Diseases Control revealed that the man had tested positive for the Covid- virus.  At the heart of the outbreak in February, China had also confirmed cases where people who appeared to have recovered and tested negative were later found to have tested positive, confounding the popular belief that those who survive would be immune at least in the immediate future from catching the disease again. It is reportedly the first time it has happened in Vietnam. Vietnamese officials were unable to say why the disease appeared to have reappeared again and said they had ordered officials to investigate where the man might have come into contact with it again.

title: coronavirus frontline workers cry happy
story: NewsCoronavirus frontline workers cry ‘happy tears’ as volunteers print D face shieldsVolunteers D printed , protective face shields over the Easter weekend to support those on the coronavirus frontline with money donated by the public to the D Crowd UK campaignShareCommentsByPhoebe Davis:,  APR NewsToby Johnson, , is one of over  volunteers who have joined DCrowdUK " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWe will use your email address to send you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid Email Volunteers across the country have D printed tens of thousands of protective face shields to aid frontline healthcare workers treating Covid- patients. Over , face shields were dispatched by volunteers with access to D printing equipment over Easter weekend thanks to money raised by online crowdfunding campaign D Crowd UK.The campaign asks those with resources to D print protective equipment to lend their support, paid for by donations from members of the public. The crowdfunded project has raised more than £, and received more than  requests for at least , face shields, since launching in March.More than  frontline NHS staff have died during the coronavirus pandemic in the UK amid criticism from the government over not providing adequate supplies of Personal Protective Equipment .Faces of the NHS heroes who have died during the coronavirus pandemicOn Saturday, Home Secretary Priti Patel said she was ‘sorrypeople think there have been PPE failings’. Although D Crowd UK have fundraised £, through their GoFundMe page to support their efforts, it is not enough to keep up to the increasing demand.Gen Ashley, one of the leaders of  D Crowd UK, said: “The orders we’ve received from health and social care organisations demonstrate just how critical the shortage of protective equipment is for frontline workers in the UK. “We are hoping to produce more because we have already seen that the demand is greater than what we were aiming to do, and the crowdfunding needs to continue to get the material we need.” Ben Sauer, also on the DCrowd UK team, said: “We hear first-hand from those on the front line about how desperately they need this equipment and with the help of the volunteers we can really make a dference to people who are treating those worst affected by coronavirus.” The shields have been gratefully received by NHS workers, who have been sharing their support for the campaign on social media.Helen Kilminster, a pharmacist from Worcestershire tweeted that when she received a call from DCrowdUK telling her that  shields have been dispatched to her, she “Actually cried. Happy tears. Relieved tears.” Toby Johnson, , is one of over  volunteers who have joined DCrowdUK. He is staying up overnight and giving up his Easter break to print the face shields at his home in Surrey. Toby said: “It’s been amazing to work virtually with like-minded people who all share the same goal using modern technology to help the NHS in this current time.” In Yorkshire, engineers from the University of Sheffield are also working around the clock to print and distribute the protective face shields. Dr Pete Mylon, the project leader from the University’s Department of Mechanical Engineering, said: “Doctors, nurses and other healthcare workers across the country are in need of PPE. Many staff are anxious about not having the right equipment and potentially exposing themselves to infection.” The coronavirus lockdown is a worrying time for millions across the UK. But itaposs also bringing out the best in people who are selflessly giving their time each day to help those most in need. Our Mirror Coronavirus Heroes series wants to recognise all of those helping the most vulnerable during the crisis. Whether itaposs a local business going the extra mile for the community or a teenager helping an elderly neighbour, we want to hear about it. You can email your stories of Mirror Coronavirus Heroes to webnews@mirror. Dr Sam Pashneh-Tala, who is also involved in the project and an expert in bioengineering from the University’s Department of Materials Science and Engineering, added: “I knew we could do something so we assembled a team and are doing what we can to help. We will keep doing it until someone tells us to stop.” It isn’t just members of the public donating money to support the volunteers efforts across the country. The rd Holmesfield Scout Group in Dronfield, Sheffield donated acetate sheets to use as the disposable guard in the face shields. To get the face shields where they are needed, the shields are being picked up from the DCrowdUK volunteers around the country by delivery service DPD, free of charge.

Devastated Candice Blythe said she never imagined the final time she ever laid eyes on mum Anne, would be in the back of an ambulance as the doors closed. The mum-of-three had been surprised by daughters Candice and Louise, , for an early Motheraposs Day meal on March , but by the following week was showing early symptoms of the virus including a cough and fatigue. Despite initially appearing to get better, Anne, , was later rushed to hospital and after five days in Harlowaposs Princess Alexandra Hospital Anne took a turn for the worse.  On the morning of Friday, April , doctors were forced to increase her ventilator oxygen levels to  per cent - and by pm the same day, she had had died from multi-organ failure. Paying tribute to her much-loved aposbeautul and kindapos mum, Candice, who appeared on BBC Breakfast this morning, is now begging Brits to take the pandemic seriously. The credit controller said: You just donapost think itaposs going to hit you, and then it just comes along and throws you this massive, devastating curveball.  I never believed or thought for a moment that when the paramedics were shutting the door on me as I waved goodbye to my mum in the back of an ambulance it would be the last time I ever saw her. For the first five days in hospital her condition was stable and we were all feeling hopeful. But by Friday she had done a  turn, she was on the maximum amount of oxygen they could give her and the hospital staff were telling us there was nothing they could do to save her.  Every single one of her organs was failing. By pm that day she had died, thataposs all it took to ravage her body from the inside out - a matter of hours. I know people lose their parents eventually, but in normal circumstances you would be able to be at their bedside and say goodbye to them.  We didnapost get any of that and my mum was still so young. Our -year-old nan has outlived her own daughter, sheaposs absolutely beside herself. Candice lived at home with her mum to help care for her sister, Louise, who was left disabled by a brain tumour at  months old, and her mum, who had chronic back pain.  Anneaposs youngest daughter was prompted to call the ambulance when she went to check on her mum in the morning and found her lips were blue but her body was red, hot and blotchy, despite her complaining she felt cold. Even with those alarming symptoms, Candice said she wasnapost overly worried about Covid- as her mum was still her usual self - joking with the paramedics to aposget off her carpetsapos with their boots on.But concerned the -year-old could have coronavirus, the ambulance crew wouldnapost let Candice travel to hospital with her mum, and she was forced to leave Anne with just her mobile phone to keep in touch.Three days later tests confirmed she had the virus and although her condition remained stable, Anne had been moved to a ward where there was no phone signal and the family were instead given daily updates by medics. But after nearly a week of hopeful news her daughters received the devastating blow that their mum had been put on a ventilator and her organs were starting to shut down and she died just hours later. As well as her devastated daughters, the gran-of-two leaves behind her own mum, Vally, , and five siblings - prompting Candice to beg Brits to take the governmentaposs self-isolation advice seriously. Candice said: She was such a beautul, kind woman, everybody loved her and we were such a close family. We are absolutely broken.  We are so grateful to the hospital staff and we are still trying to find out who was with her in her last moments so we can thank them for not letting her go on her own. I just didnapost think this virus was going to get her, because she has been through and survived so much with her back and even survived a cervical cancer scare. The loving pair had not left their home for weeks because of the threat of coronavirus, but Pat, , started feeling unwell on Saturday, April .Bryn, , became ill as well and they were taken to hospital last Thursday, where they tested positive for Covid-, Wales Online reports.Their devastated family have paid tribute to the pillars of the community and thanked everyone for the outpouring of the support they had received. Sadly, Pat died on Monday at am and her husband died later that day at pm. Elliot said: We are trying to take some comfort in the fact they died together, after  years of joyous marriage. Nanny, especially, was so well. We always said she was a very young -year-old, and she had decades left in her.  It is just horric and such a shock. They had four sons - Andrew, Barrie, Keith and Bleddyn - as well as two honorary daughters, Carolyn and Claire, who they had helped to look after from the age of six months,  grandchildren,  great-grandchildren, with another two on the way. Elliot says: Their home had an open door and their house was so full of love. They took such pride in their family and we loved celebrating their diamond anniversary just a few months ago. Nanny was elated to receive a card from the Queen. We are such a close family. Most of the family live within a short drive of their home. When we come out of this coronavirus crisis, it would be disastrous to repeat the foolish mistakes of . Then, Conservative austerity was a political choice which snuffed out a promising economic recovery, squeezed wages and sunk the NHS on to its knees. Two million extra unemployed and soaring public debt require calm heads… not panic. New visions… not bankrupt Tory cuts. Investing in the future… not yet more slashing. So we demand the Government stands firm and imposes its % digital sales tax instead of caving in to self-interested global giants. The £million-odd the Treasury ­estimates it will raise is a touch on the low side anyway.

Some have been entirely asymptomatic, meaning they show no signs of Covid-, but have tested positive, while others can experience symptoms ranging from mild to those which require emergency care.Many people who have experienced mild symptoms, including a fever, fatigue, dry cough, shortness of breath, and loss of taste and smell, but havenapost been tested may suspect they have already had coronavirus.The problem is the milder symptoms can mirror those experienced with more common illnesses, like a cold, making it dficult to diagnose. Dr William Hillmann, an associate inpatient physician director at Massachusetts General Hospital, explains that the only way to tellsomeone has already had coronavirus would be with an antibody test. It would allow experts to check blood samples for antibodies against the virus, but these are still being developed and are not yet in widespread clinical use.Dr Hillmann told: I, and I think many others, are anxiously awaiting for those to become available. He explains that even those who have had coronavirus with no symptoms are still contagious for a period of time, but aposwe just donapost know for how long at this pointapos. People who may believe they have coronavirus should act no dferently to those who donapost, for the safety of themselves and others around them. Dr Hillmann says: Since there’s no real way to know at this point who might have had it, unless you’re symptomatic, you get a swab and are definitively diagnosed with it, I would just act asyou hadn’t had it. Keep doing all of those things that we all should be doing at this point: social distancing and hand hygiene. Although those who have had coronavirus are expected to build an immunity to it, at least for a short period of time, at this point it still remains unclearthe same person can catch it twice.

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA medical examiner diagnosed with coronavirus may be the first case of the virus caught from a dead body, scientists suggest.The examiner, from Bangkok, Thailand, may have contracted the disease from an infected body in March, according the Journal of Forensic and Legal Medicine Study. Won Sriwijitalai of the RVT Medical Center in Bangkok and Viroj Wiwanitkit of Hainan Medical University in China, the authors of the study, wrote: Forensic professionals have to wear protective devices including a protective suit, gloves, goggles, cap and mask. The disinfection procedure used in operation rooms might be applied in pathology forensic units too. According to our best knowledge, this is the first report on Covid- infection and death among medical personnel in a Forensic Medicine unit. Follow all coronavirus updates on our live blog here The number of cases of coronavirus in Thailand is now , - with  deaths. On contracting the virus from a dead body, the World Health Organisation says there is a low chance of contraction apart fromminimal caution is taking while handling infected lungs. It explains: Except in cases of hemorrhagic feversand cholera, dead bodies are generally not infectious. Only the lungs of patients with pandemic influenza,handled improperly during an autopsy, can be infectious. To date there is no evidence of persons having become infected from exposure to the bodies of persons who died from Covid-.  In the UK,  NHS workers have lost their lives to the virus. Medics are repeating their calls for more support and more PPE as they battle the spread of coronavirus on the frontline. Yesterday, Dominic Raab, who has stepped in for Boris Johnson who remains in recovery, said  million items of PPE had been delivered over the bank holiday weekend. He said: “We understand the importance of getting PPE to the front line whether it’s in care homes or the NHS.

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid Email After weeks in the grip of the coronavirus pandemic, parts of Europe are beginning to ease lockdown measures on their populations in a step towards normality.Italy and Spain were among the first European countries to put their populations on lockdown - with some of the worldaposs most famous cities falling silent. Once bustling bars, restaurants and cafes have had their shutters closed for almost two months - with many businesses across the continent fearing they wonapost be able to bounce back from the pandemic. But on Monday, Spanish authorities began allowing some workers toto their jobs after restrictions on non-essential industries were lted. Builders, cleaners and factory workers were permitted to travel to work again, as police officers in the city were seen handing out face masks in the cityaposs metro stations. Officials say social distancing and a ban on non-essential travel will remain in place. In Italy the lockdown largely remains in place, but some bookshops and clothes stores will begin opening from Tuesday April . After the UK government announced the lockdown is likely to remain in place for another three weeks, hereaposs how other countries are moving forward.Follow all coronavirus updates on our live blog hereSpain  Spain announced a partial easing of its lockdown on Monday, as the first non-essential workers were pictured travelling across the city. The country has been one of the worst hit by Covid- in Europe with the killer virus claiming the lives of , people so far. As the country enters its second month of lockdown, some businesses that cannot operate remotely, including construction and manufacturing, were allowed to reopen on Monday. However the controversial decision has sparked criticism from some regional leaders who fear a resurgence of the outbreak. Workers allowed toto their jobs were given masks to wear when they arrived at transport hubs. But the majority of the population are still confined to their homes, while shops, bars and public spaces will remain closed until at least April . Italy  Italy has been one of the hardest-hit countries in Europe and has so-far recorded , cases of the virus - and , deaths. Lombardy has been the worst affected region, suffering more than , cases and accounting for around half of the countryaposs death toll. Lockdown measures were introduced on March , with events suspended and schools closed. By March , non-essential movement had been banned and all non-essential manufacturing was stopped on March . After alarming day-on-day rises of deaths in recent weeks, the numbers have been falling  in recent days. From today, non-essential shops such as book shops  and clothes stores will begin to open. Social distancing measures however will remain in place and gathering will not be permitted. Germany Germany has recorded , cases of coronavirus and , deaths to date. The first case was recorded on January  and lockdown measures started to be issued on March . By March , all non-essential travel was banned, schools had closed and the countryaposs land borders had been shut. Non-essential shops and factories have remained open during the partial lockdown and schools could be re-opened next week. The government plans on handing out masks to the publiclockdown measures are lted as planned. France  France has , cases of coronavirus and has recorded , deaths. Events across the country were suspended on February  and by March  all non-essential travel had been banned, schools closed and shops closed. Yesterday, French president Emmanuel Macron announced the country will remain in its current lockdown state until May . He said after this date, another assessment will be taken on whether to reopen schools and creches. Sweden  Sweden has taken a dferent approach to much of Europe in that it has not enforced any official lockdown and has instead advised people try and social distance themselves as much as possible. Authorities in the northern region of Norrbotten warned locals to stay aposone moose apos away from one another in.  Shops, bars and restaurants have remained open across the country however Prime Minister Stefan Lofven warns stricter lockdown measures could be put in placethe situation worsens. Austria  Austria has so-far recorded  deaths, with its first case being recorded on February . On March  events across the country were cancelled and schools closed five days later. By March , land borders had been closed, all non-essential shops shut and non-essential movement was banned. From today, non-essential shops will begin to re-open, including DIY stores and garden centres. Shopping centres, department stores and hair salons are to reopen from May  and by mid-May, restaurants and hotels are expected to open. United Kingdom  Dominic Raab has said the Government will not consider lting the UK coronavirus lockdown this week.The Foreign Secretary said the UK was still not past the peak of the virus and added that we donapost expect to make any changes to the measures currently in place after scientic advisory groupmeets later this week. title: a job for life charismatic muriel loved her university of dundee job so much she only managed to retire for 10 weeks
story: From the second I step through the revolving doors of Dundee University#s Tower Building, I know exactly who Muriel Duncan is. An email exchange that took place with one of the institution#s staff prior to our interview said that the -year-old embodied #everything that is good about the university#.That doesn#t even begin to cover it. Muriel, who has held numerous roles since first starting  years ago, is warm, friendly and funny. In fact, she#s the sort of person -year-oldme would have loved to have met on my first day at Edinburgh University eight years ago.Although she might not have been able to help me, she has given support to thousands of other students who have passed through the doors of Dundee University over the years.Excluding a -week period in  when Muriel retired # we#ll get to that in a bit # she has been a permanent fixture at the university. In October , she started as a clerical assistant at the faculty of science.At that time the department did #everything# as far as students were concerned, including dealing with inquiry and admissions letters. She stayed in the role until , before moving into a position working directly with postgraduate students.#I loved it,# she explains. #I really enjoyed all the work with overseas students.# Muriel witnessed plenty of changes in the years that followed postgraduate student numbers soared from around  in the early s to , at the turn of the century and new buildings sprung up around the campus.#We moved from Cross Row, onto the seventh floor of the Tower Building, before ending up at Airlie Place,# she says. The busiest time of the year was always that four-month period between June and October, as the team worked constantly to ensure the admissions process ran smoothly.#It was just mad during that time. I was working a lot of overtime, coming to work in the evenings and catching up but I thoroughly enjoyed it.#There were four of us working in the office at one point. We all worked brilliantly together and did each other favours. We still all keep in contact two of them are still at the university.#In  Muriel made the decision to retire, but only managed  weeks before ing to work # this time in a dferent role. She#d passed a remark to a colleague, around six months prior to her retirement, about an ambition to work on the university reception at one stage.#And then, after I was away for  weeks, I got a phone call one morning and he said to me #you once said that you would like to work in the reception. Well, we#re looking for someone now.# ##When can I start # I replied. He said to me, #I think you need to discuss that with your husband# and I said #oh there#ll be no discussion,# she tells me, laughing hysterically.I ask her why she retired in the first place. #I think I just needed a break,# she says.#They were wanting to expand things and change things and they probably felt #well that old soul won#t change.# I felt it was maybe time to hang up the reins and let someone  have an opportunity.# Now, Muriel works part-time from Monday to Friday and loves every second of it. #It#s good to meet people and I think that when you#re older, you need something like this,# she says.#This sitting around the house would drive me mad. We were off for two weeks over Christmas and on that weekend before ing to work, my husband asked me #what are you thinking about going back to work # I said #oh, I can#t wait.#

title: a job for life loyalty to boots has kept mo in her dream role for 40 years
story: For Maureen McCabe, working as a pharmacy delivery driver is pretty much a dream job. The -year-old recently celebrated  years service at Boots and can#t quite put her finger on what it is that has kept her at the company for so long.She thinks it#s a combination of factors from her love of driving and passion for working with prescriptions, to her friendships with colleagues and relationships with staff working in the surgeries and shops across the city.I ask Maureenshe remembers the date of when she first started working at Boots. It#s clear it is etched in her memory as she tells me without faltering: #January st . I started as a sales assistant in Lochee before moving onto the chemist counter, approximately two years later.#After that, Maureen transferred to the site#s store on Reform Street where she worked on the photo-lab and in the children#s department.Finally, she found her calling and took on the #cushy# van driver role. She#s now been doing that job for  years, and hasn#t looked back once.#I love my job. For some reason, I#ve always loved working with prescriptions picking them up from doctor surgeries and delivering them to stores across the city,# she says.#The thing about this job is you maintain great relationships with the surgeries and shops and you feel really close to all their members of staff.#I#m very loyal to Boots because they#ve treated me so well over the years. Plus, we all work as a team I#m always having a gossip with my colleagues. Instead of getting called Maureen, they call me Mo. There are only two people amongst the shops and surgeries that call me by my actual name. When I come back after a week#s holiday a lot of them say, #oh we#re glad to see you back Mo.# I just love it.#The Monieth resident, who works Monday to Friday from around am to pm, has always gone above and beyond in her role.#The customers used to come in and say #I want Maureen to serve me. She knows what I#m wanting.# I was that good with them. I#ve always had a brilliant rapport with them.#There have been a lot of change over the years, including managers and other things that I think should have just been kept the way they were, but you#ve got to move with the times you have to adapt.#We#re doing things like e-learning now which we never used to have to do. We#ve not been affected by the internet yet, but seemingly it#s coming. Some of the stores, such as the one on Reform Street, send their scripts away and get them back a couple of days later all packed up. So there are changes coming.#I don#t think there is a #hardest# part of my job. I#ve no worries when it comes to doing this role. I think it#s great you#re out-and-about, you#re your own boss.#It#s been a really good time for me, these last  years. I didn#t think I would last it myself, but I have. I don#t know why it came to be that I ended up in this job, but it#s a dream job. I#ve got another two-and-a-half years till I retire andI keep going like this, I#ll be absolutely fine!#

title: dundee fc dundee united title spfl vote
story: Dundee could decide Dundee United’s promotion fate after a day of chaos in Scottish football.Tele Sport understands the Dark Blues are the Championship side whose vote on the SPFL resolution to “call” the season has not yet been counted.As a result, with the plan having been passed by Premiership, League One and League Two Clubs, Dundee now hold the power to decide whether the League’s plan succeeds or fails.A vote in favour would see the season terminated in Scotland’s bottom three isions, prize money distributed, and Dundee United declared Championship title winners.A vote against will send the SPFL back to the drawing board.The Tangerines were tonight staying tight-lipped on the situation.However, their city rivals issued a y statement in which they notably failed to confirm which way they had voted –indeed they had at all – then called for an alternative approach.“As we all know, clubs are struggling at the moment,” read the Dark Blues’ communique.“The language in the currentproposal condemns clubs to be financially worse off than they already are as we sit here today. This has been dficult to accept.“The SPFL board and executive freely admit that they focused on the sporting merit of the proposal and did not take into consideration any financial fall out to their member clubs.“Fundamentally, we believe that in these exceptional and uncertain times, no member club should be worse off as a result of this proposal than they are today.“The current proposal will see member clubs cumulatively have in the region of £.-£ million pounds of lost revenue.“Amongst the member clubs there have been numerous discussions of the SPFL’s offer as well as viable, equitable proposed alternatives that could see, potentially, a neutral outcome for all clubs involvedthe season cannot be finished.“In all cases, current placement monies could be distributed to the member clubs in very short order while maintaining all SPFL obligations.“Make no mistake we would have to work quickly and diligently to ensure that members’ current needs are met and that the democratic process is followed, but it is achievable.”An SPFL spokesperson added: “It is very important that clubs consider carefully the resolution and we are grateful to those clubs who have voted already.“With the Ladbrokes Premiership and Ladbrokes Leagues One and Two isions each having approved the resolution, we await the voting slip from the one Ladbrokes Championship club that has yet to vote.“We will provide an update as soon as we are in a position to do so.”The SPFL set an initial deadline of pm for clubs to vote.However it is understood league rules give members  days to vote on resolutions – and Dundee are keen to weigh up their options.It is believed Partick Thistle and Inverness Caley Thistle were the two Championship sides to vote against the plan.As a result, Dundee appear to be in a position to set whichever agenda they please in negotiations with the SPFL.🔵 In these troubled times, when many people are struggling to get out for their paper, we are pledging to Our view on that has not changed.#Over the past few days, we have entered into ious positive discussions with reconstruction at the forefront of these.#Given our discussions and considering all aspects, we don’t feel we are in a position to comment further on the resolution that was put forward.#We understand that this may bring more questions than answers and we will look to give a much more substantial account of the past few days at the conclusion of this process.#Our supporters should know that we are, as always, looking out for the best interests of both Dundee Football Club and Scottish football as a whole.#The Dens Park club issued the statement ahead of an expected SPFL board meeting later on this evening.🔵 In these troubled times, when many people are struggling to get out for their paper, we are pledging to help readers by providing a FREE digital edition of the Eveningfor three months.
